item.title: Ticket #2144 (linking error numbers to reference) closed
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
wontfix:

Because it's only "developers and weekend hackers" that see mysql errors (and even they shouldn't be seeing them often), it's only a very small user group that would benefit from this addition.

And for those power users it's easy enough to just copy and past the error to Google, if they don't know what it means already.

Furthermore, we don't have any control whatsoever on the content on that site, so I'm not in favor of including links to it in core.

item.title: Ticket #2830 (Change the way t he domain is being retrieved for sending e-mails from ...) closed
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
wontfix:

I agree with westi. I'd rather see this implemented as a plugin than cluttering the core with an option that only a small subset of the users will ever use.

I've taken westi's example one step further and added a configuration page to it, so you can set the email adres from the admin section. (The largly untested statement still stands though)

item.title: customsender.php attached to Ticket #2830
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description: Plugin.

item.title: Ticket #2830 (Change the way t he domain is being retrieved for sending e-mails from ...) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Owner, Status changed

I don't think this needs to be a core feature.

A very simple plugin (untested but should work fine) can be used to replace the builtin wp_mail function with one that sends from another address: 

/*
   Plugin Name: Override Email Address
   Description: Allows you to override the email address used by wp_mail
   Author: Peter Westwood
   Version: 0.01
   Author URI: http://blog.ftwr.co.uk/
 */
function wp_mail($to, $subject, $message, $headers = '') {
	if( $headers == '' ) {
		$headers = "MIME-Version: 1.0\n" .
		"From: user@domain \n" .
		"Content-Type: text/plain; charset=\"" . get_settings('blog_charset') . "\"\n";
	}
	return @mail($to, $subject, $message, $headers);
}

Replacing user@domain in the above plugin and activating it will allow you to pick the email address you want the emails to originate from.

This plugin works because wp_mail is one of the pluggable functions that a plugin can override by defining it before WordPress

item.title: Ticket #3315 (Language files in wp-content) updated
item.dc:creator: idle
item.description:
In response to Ryan's comment:

Because future upgrades will overwrite the modified files, unless you want to manually update your files. Adding new files to wp-includes or wp-admin is a whole different arm, however.

Personally, I never delete my wp-includes directory, but keep my global functions in a file of its own inside that directory. Anyway, I like this patch. Nice work, Nazgul!

item.title: Ticket #3322 (Problems with non latin characters in user names) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Version, Milestone changed

Usernames need to be A-Z and 0-9 plus a couple other standard characters I think like - and _. This is for code and other reasons to ensure one can login no matter the charset and things like that (stubs too).

Display names exist so that you can show users in a different way with whatever characters you want.

However, the change profile page probably shouldn't check the username since the field is disabled and for backwards compatibility such as this.

item.title: Ticket #3325 (Admin menu shows item user can't use) created
item.dc:creator: ovgray
item.description:
K2 and the sidebar widgets plugin both add submenu items to the Presentation (theme.php) admin menu item by calling add_submenu_page() with an access level parameter of '5' rather than one of the newer capabilities.

When either K2 or the widgets plugin is active in a version 2.1alpha3 site, a user with 'editor' capabilities (which include access level '5') will see a 'Presentation' link to themes.php in the admin menu, but on clicking that link the user sees "You do not have sufficient permissions to access this page."

item.dc:creator: sotirios
item.description:
Hi guys. I reported following problem in the support forum and people suggested i report it as a bug.

The problem: user names in my blog were all in greek. I didnt have a problem, until now.

But the last months (possibly after an upgrade to wordpress 2) whenever i try to change a user's profile i get a silly message

ERROR: This username is invalid. Please enter a valid username.

Can anyone help?

item.title: Ticket #3299 (clean_url() not working for non-HTTP URLS) updated
item.dc:creator: JeremyVisser
item.description:
Version, Component changed

I encounter this also when changing my Blog and WordPress addresses (Options > General) to be relative addresses, which shows it is not a templating problem.

For example, I had a WordPress running on localhost, which had the address http://localhost/wordpress as the address. Of course, when I navigated to that WP from another computer, all the stylesheets and links were broken because they were still pointing to localhost.

What saved me in early 2.0 versions was simply changing the http://localhost/wordpress to /wordpress, and that worked fine. Well, the RSS feed links broke but that didn't matter. Something's changed in the URL validation in 2.0.5 (it may have been 2.0.4 or 2.0.3, I don't know. It worked in 2.0.2, though) that forces all URLs to have a http:// at the beginning.

I had a valid reason for not having a http://, so WP shouldn't be forcing me to.

P.S. I had to manually edit my MySQL tables after the above saga, because I couldn't log on because WP tried to load http:///wp-login.php.

item.title: Ticket #3321 (Empty list item in default theme's sidebar) created
item.dc:creator: idle
item.description:
In theme Default, the "You are currently browsing..." section is sometimes empty, resulting in an empty list item. Tried it with a fresh installation of 2.0.5 as well as 2.1-alpha3 from SVN.

Attached is a patch that'll take care of the empty LI by surrounding each "currently browsing..." part with LIs, rather than the entire section whereas the conditions may return false.

Pardon the nitpicking. ;)
